The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.p:
OF Repairing and Mending THE HIGHWAYS In Five Sections, TOUCHING,
I. Removing Ob≈øtructions in the Highways, and Scouring the Ditches next adjoining.
II. Draining the Highways, and Repairing them.
III. Providing Material.
IV. Providing Labourers.
V. Providing Carriages.
Publi≈øhed for the U≈øe and In≈øtruction of Young SURVEYORS.
By WILLIAM MATHER, a Late Surveyor of the Highways in BEDFORD.
LONDON, Printed for Samuel Clark, in George-yard, in Lombard-≈øtreet. 1696.

div.head: OF Repairing and Mending THE HIGHVVAYS.
Section I. Of Removing Ob≈øtructions in the Highways, and Scouring the Ditches next adjoining.
div.p:
Fir≈øt, BEfore you begin to repair the Highways with any Stone, Gravel, or other Materials, take care to ≈øee that all Ditches and Drains adjoining thereunto, be opened, and ≈øcoured, and made deep, or low enough to carry
all ≈øtanding Water out of the ≈øame Highways, where the Water is an Annoyance. Al≈øo ≈øee that all Trees and Bu≈øhes growing in or next adjoining to the Highways, and ob≈øtructing the ea≈øie pa≈ø≈øage of the People, be cut down, or kept low. And if the Owner of the Ground, or Soil, to which the Ditches, Trees, Hedges, or Bu≈øhes do belong, ≈øhall neglect to keep them ≈øo ≈øeour'd and cut as afore≈øaid, then you mu≈øt pre≈øent him, within one Month after default, to the next Ju≈øtice of the Peace, who is to certifie the ≈øame at the next General Se≈ø≈øions, where the Defaulter is to be Fined at the Di≈øcretion of the Ju≈øtices, 5 Eliz. Cap. 13. And 18 Eliz. Cap. 10. according to the 5 Eliz. Cap. 13. but according to the 18 Eliz. Cap. 10. the Defaulter ≈øhall Forfeit for every Default Ten Shillings.

Secondly, See that the Earth and Soil ca≈øt out of the Ditches or Drains into the Highways, be not ≈øuffered to lye there by the ≈øpace of Six Months, to the Annoyance of the Highways; but be carried off within
that time, by him that holds the Ground next adjoining, and that ≈øcoured the Ditch. 18 Eliz. Cap. 10. Which if he ≈øhall neglect to do, he Forfeits Twelve Pence for every Load ≈øo ca≈øt up, and you are to pre≈øent his default at next Quarter Se≈ø≈øions.

Thirdly, See that all Ditches and Drains, in any Ground adjoining to the ≈øaid Ground adjoining to the Highways, where any ditching or ≈øcouring ought to be, for conveying the Water out of the Highway, over the Ground next adjoining, be kept from time to time, as need requires, ditched and ≈øcoured: 18 Eliz. Cap. 10. ¬ß 6. and 9. And if he that holds that Ground ≈øhall neglect to keep the ≈øame ≈øo ditched and ≈øcoured, he Forfeits Twelve Pence for every Rod not ≈øo done and kept, and you are to pre≈øent his default at next Quarter Se≈ø≈øions.

Fourthly, See if there be any Springs or Water-cour≈øes in the Highways, making them deep and dangerous; and if there be, you have
full Authority to turn the ≈øame into any Ditch of the ≈øeveral Ground of any Per≈øon next adjoining to the ≈øaid Highways, 5 Eliz. Cap. 13. in ≈øuch manner as you ≈øhall think mo≈øt convenient.

Tho≈øe are the means appointed by the Old Statutes (≈øtill in force) for draining the Highways in general, whether they be more or le≈øs than Twenty Foot broad: But for the draining and clearing ≈øuch Highways as are not Twenty Foot broad, there are other additional Means appointed in the Late Statute made for the better Repairing of them, 3 and 4 W. and M. which be the≈øe that follow:

Fir≈øt, Every Per≈øon that lays in any ≈øuch Highway any Timber, Stone, Straw, 3 and 4 W. and M. or other Matter what≈øoever, whereby the ≈øame ≈øhall be ob≈øtructed or annoyed, Forfeits for every ≈øuch Offence Five Shillings, to be Levied by Warrant of Two Ju≈øtices of your Divi≈øion, or in default thereof, any Neighbouring Ju≈øtices.

Secondly, Every Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of Lands next adjoining to the Highway where any ≈øuch Matter lyes, mu≈øt remove the ≈øame, 3 and 4 W. and M. (and may take it to his own U≈øe) which if he neglects to do within Ten Days after you have given him notice, he Forfeits al≈øo Five Shillings, to be Levied as afore≈øaid, for every ≈øuch neglect.

Thirdly, If any Tree, Bu≈øh, or Shrub, ≈øhall ≈øtand or grow in ≈øuch Highway, and be not cut down and carried away by the Owner of the Soil, where the ≈øame doth ≈øtand or grow, 3 and 4 W. and M. within Ten Days after you have given him notice, he ≈øhall Forfeit Five Shillings for every neglect, to be Levied as afore≈øaid.

Note al≈øo, That you are required under the Penalty of Five Pounds, to pre≈øent upon Oath to one of the next Ju≈øtices, within Fourteen Days after your fir≈øt Acceptance of your Office, and ≈øo from time to time, every Four Months, during the ≈øame, the ≈øtate and condition of all the Roads, Common Highways, Water-cour≈øes, Bridges, Cau≈øeys, and Pavements within your Pari≈øh, 3 and 4 W. and M. which are to be repaired at your Pari≈øh Charge.

And I mu≈øt crave leave al≈øo to Note, That it ≈øeems very equal and rea≈øonable, That when Ditches, and Drains next the Highway, which are to be ≈øcoured by the Tenant (who Labours hard, and fares meanly, to pay his Rent) are once a Year ≈øufficiently ≈øcoured by him, and the Soil carried away; then the ≈øame ≈øhould afterwards, for that Year, be kept in repair by you: For they are afterward out of repair, only by the pa≈ø≈øing of Carts, Hor≈øes, and other Cattel in the Common Highway, and not by the Tenant's default.

div.head: Section II. Of Draining the Highways, and Repairing them.
div.p:
Fir≈øt, WHen you have removed the Annoyances, and cau≈øed the Ditches and Drains next adjoining to the Highways, to be ≈øufficiently opened and ≈øcoured by the Owners of the Soil, then do you cau≈øe all the ≈øtanding Water in the Highway, to be drained or conveyed into tho≈øe Ditches and Drains, by new Trenches or Gutters; which ought to be con≈øtantly done, e≈øpecially after every great fall of Rain; for if the Water ≈øtands long in any part of the Highways, they will be ≈øoon marred, and then require more Charge to be repaired, e≈øpecially in Clayey Ground. And (in truth) the ≈øuffering of Water to ≈øtand in the Highways, e≈øpecially in tho≈øe that
are much Carted, is the fir≈øt and principal Cau≈øe of their decay and ruin.

Secondly, After the Water is drained out of the Highways, and the Ground become dry, then, and not before, lay on your Materials for repairing; except in Winter-time there happens to be Gulls, or ≈øuch deep Holes which renders the Ways impa≈ø≈øible, and ≈øo require pre≈øent mending.

Thirdly, Where the Rutts, or Padways are deep, fir≈øt lay Faggots, or Bu≈øhes of white or black Thorn cro≈øs-way, ≈øuffering them to be cru≈øhed down by Loaden Carts drawn over; and when you lay Stones on them, then omit not to cover the Stones with Gravel, or ≈øuch like hard Rubbi≈øh; for this will get into the empty ≈øpaces between the Stones, and ≈øo fa≈øten them together, that Cartwheels and Hor≈øe-feet cannot ea≈øily di≈øplace them, which otherwi≈øe would be, and your Charge half lo≈øt.

That which doth much Gull and Marr the Common Highway, is the draught of Waggons and Carts with Burdens of exceeding weight, as 40, 50, 60, and ≈øometimes 70 Hundred Weight; one of tho≈øe Carriages doth more hurt to the Way than twenty of others, everyone ≈øeverally Loaden but with Twenty Hundred. There was (indeed) a Remedy provided again≈øt this Inconvenience, by the Statute 14 Car. 14 Car. 2. Cap. 5. 2. Cap. 5: wherein the Carriage in a Cart or Waggon was limitted to 20 Hundred Weight, between the Fir≈øt of October and the Fir≈øt of May; and to 30 Hundred between the Fir≈øt of May and the Fir≈øt of October; but that Law is expired, and ≈øo you have no Remedy in this Ca≈øe, until it ≈øhall plea≈øe the Parliament to provide one.

Fourthly, You are required, under ≈øuch Penalty as the Ju≈øtices ≈øhall impo≈øe, not exceeding Forty Shillings, to ≈øuffer no Travelling Waggon, 22 Car. 2. Cap. 12. Wayn, Cart, or Carriage, wherein any Burdens, Goods, or Wares are carried,
to pa≈øs your Highways with above Five Hor≈øe-bea≈øts at length; except only ≈øuch Carts and Carriages as are employed in and about Husbandry, and Manuring of Lands, and in the Carrying of Hay, Straw, Corn unthre≈øht, Coal, Chalk, Timber for Shipping, Materials for Building, Stones of all ≈øorts, or ≈øuch Ammunition or Artillery which ≈øhall be for His Maje≈øties Service.

And for your Encouragement, if you prove the Offence by one Credible Witne≈øs upon Oath, before any Ju≈øtice of the Peace, he is to grant you a Warrant for Di≈øtraining of the Goods and Chattels of the Offender, for the Sum of Forty Shillings; one third thereof to the Poor of the Pari≈øh, another third towards repairing the Highway, and the other third to you or him that di≈øcovered the Offence.

Fifthly, Remember, that you are required to make every Cart-way leading to any Market-Town, Eight Foot wide at the lea≈øt, 3 and 4 W. and M. and as near as may be, even and level; and every
Cau≈øey for Hor≈øes Travelling, at the lea≈øt Three Foot in breadth.

div.head: Section III. Of Providing Materials.
div.p: Fir≈øt, YOU may lawfully cau≈øe Stones lying upon any Lands or Ground within your Pari≈øh, 5 Eliz. 13. to be gathered and carried for the amendment of the Highways.

Secondly, You may take and carry away ≈øo much of the Rubbi≈øh, or ≈ømall broken Stones, of any Quarries in your Pari≈øh, as you ≈øhall think nece≈ø≈øary for the mending of the Highways, without Licence of the Owner; Provided you find the Rubbi≈øh or Stones ready digged by the Owner; for it is not lawful for you to cau≈øe them to be digged out of the Quarry.

Thirdly, In ca≈øe ≈øuch Rubbi≈øh cannot be found there, then it is lawful for you to dig for Gravel, Sand, or Cinders, 5 Eliz. 13. in any Per≈øons ≈øeveral Ground within your Pari≈øh, nigh adjoining to the Way that is to be repaired, and wherein Gravel, and ≈øuch ≈øtuff, is like to be found, and to carry away ≈øo much thereof as you ≈øhall think nece≈ø≈øary; provided that you do not dig in the Hou≈øe, Garden, Orchard, or Meadow of any Per≈øon, nor dig more than one only Pit in any ≈øeveral and enclo≈øed Ground; nor that the Pit be any way in breadth or length above Ten Yards over at the mo≈øt; nor left unfilled up again with Earth, above one Month after it hath been made. Of all which you mu≈øt be Circum≈øpect, for you Forfeit for every default you ≈øhall make therein, Five Marks to the Owner of the Soil.

Fourthly, If you have not in your Pari≈øh Gravel, Stones, Quarries, 3 and 4 W. and M. nor other Materials fitting for the amending of the Highways, by rea≈øon
whereof you are forced to lay our your own Money for the Buying of ≈øuch Materials; then upon your giving notice of the Sum Expended by you, and making Oath thereof to the Ju≈øtices at their Special Se≈ø≈øions, (which by the Late Act is to be holden once in every Four Months) they, or any two of them, are impowered to cau≈øe a Rate to be made, for the reimbur≈øing you, upon the Inhabitants of your Pari≈øh, who are to be Di≈øtrained, if they refu≈øe to pay.

div.head: Section IV. Of Providing Labourers.
div.p: Fir≈øt, EVery Hou≈øholder, and every Cottager [one that holds a Hou≈øe without Land] and every Labourer of your Pari≈øh, 2 and 3 P. and M. 5 Eliz. Cap. 13. And 18 Eliz. Cap. 10. being able to Labour, and being no Hired Servant, ≈øhall either work them≈øelves, or every one of them ≈øend a Labourer to work Six Days in every Year, in the amendment of the Highways.

Secondly, 5 Eliz. Cap. 13. 18 Eliz. Cap. 10. Every Per≈øon (except ≈øuch as Dwell in the City of London) chargeable in your Pari≈øh, but as a Cottager to the mending of the Highways, if he be A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in any Sub≈øidy or Tax to the King, ≈øo much as to Five Pounds in Goods, or Forty Shillings a Year in Lands, ≈øhall find two able Men Yearly, to Labour Six Days in the Highways.

Thirdly, Every ≈øuch Per≈øon as above≈øaid, 2 and 3 P. and M. Cap. 8. ≈øhall have and bring with them ≈øuch Shovels, Spades, Mattocks, and other Tools as are nece≈ø≈øary for their Work; and ≈øhall do and keep their Work, as you, or one of you ≈øhall appoint them, Eight Hours every of the ≈øaid Days; unle≈øs you, or one of you, ≈øhall otherwi≈øe Licen≈øe any of them.

Fourthly, 22 Car. 2. Cap. 12. The Six Days for working in the Highways, and for providing Materials, are to be appointed by you; having re≈øpect to the Weather and Sea≈øon of the Year, and giving publick notice ≈øome convenient time before the Six Days. And in ≈øuch places where the Highways cannot be ≈øufficiently repaired before Mid≈øummer, you may take time to do the ≈øame until a Fortnight after Michaelmas; but within that time they mu≈øt be repaired.

Fifthly, If any of the ≈øaid Per≈øons Chargeable, 22 Car. 2. Cap. 12. as afore≈øaid, to find Labourers for mending the Highways,
≈øhall neglect to ≈øend them to make their re≈øpective Days Labour, then you are to make Complaint thereof to the next Ju≈øtice of the Peace, who are required, upon Proof made to them of ≈øuch neglect, by the Oath of one Credible Witne≈øs, to Levy by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of the Goods of every Offender, the Sum of One Shilling and Six Pence for every Days default of every Labourer.

Al≈øo you may return all and every of the Defaulters within one Month after every default made, 22 Car. 2. Cap. 12. to ≈øome one Neighbouring Ju≈øtice of the Peace, who is to pre≈øent the ≈øame at the next Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, where the Offenders are to be Fined as the Laws and Statutes appoint.

But here (again) I mu≈øt crave leave to ≈øay, that it ≈øeems very unequal, that every poor Cottager, and Labourer, who hath not Bread for him≈øelf and Family to Eat, but what he Earns by his Labour from Day to Day, ≈øhould be Charged to Labour
him≈øelf, or to find a Labourer to work the Six Days, in repairing the common Highways. And therefore I cannot blame the Practice of ≈øome Surveyors in this Ca≈øe, e≈øpecially of tho≈øe that live in Corporate and Market Towns, where the Poor abound, in admitting the Children of Poor Cottagers and Labourers, in Lieu of their Parents, to Labour the Six Days in gathering Stones for repair of the Highways; and in Conniving at the Ab≈øence of other Poor Cottagers that have no Children to ≈øend, or in taking but a little Money of them for their defect. For the utmost of Ju≈øtice, in this Ca≈øe, would be Inju≈øtice and Oppre≈ø≈øion.

div.head: Section V. Of Providing Carriages.
div.p: Fir≈øt. EVery Per≈øon Inhabiting in your Pari≈øh, 2 and 3 P. and M. Cap 8. 5 Eliz. 13 Occupied by him, and lying in your Pari≈øh, ≈øhall ≈øend a Cart or Wayn, with Hor≈øes or Oxen, and al≈øo two able Men with the ≈øame, Six Days in every Year for the amending of the Highways.

By a Plow-land, in the Statute, is not meant the quality of Land, as Arable or Tillage, but the quantity of Lands, whether the ≈øame be Arable or Pa≈øture. In former Times the Subjects have been Taxed for all their Lands to the King, only by a Plowland, or Hyde of Land, (which are both the ≈øame). But what quantity of Land is intended by a Plow-land, all Men have not agreed; yet now it is
commonly taken and allowed to be as great a Portion of Land as may be in one Year Tilled and Laboured with one Plough: And if after that Rate, according to the be≈øt of your Judgment, you ≈øhall Charge any Occupier of Lands, either Pa≈øture or Arable, lying within your Pari≈øh, and he be Di≈øtrained for neglecting his Duty to the Highways, 18 Eliz. Cap. 10. Sect. 9. according to that Charge, he hath no Remedy if he finds him≈øelf Agrieved, but by Appealing to the Ju≈øtices of the Peace at their next General Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, where they have Power to hear and determine it.

Note, that the Occupier of a Plowland, is not Charged for the fame with re≈øpect to his or her keeping a Draught or Plow, but with re≈øpect to the quantity of Land he or ≈øhe Occupies in your Pari≈øh.

Secondly, Every other Per≈øon that keepeth a Draught or Plow in your Pari≈øh, 2 and 3 P. and M. Cap. 8. ≈øhall in like manner find and ≈øend one Wayn or Cart with Hor≈øes or
Oxen. If any Per≈øon be Charged for Occupying a Plow-land, he cannot al≈øo be Charged for keeping a Draught or Plow; and if he keeps a Draught or Plow, and Occupies no Plow-land, yet he ≈øhall be Charged for keeping a Draught or Plow.

If the Per≈øon Charged for keeping a Draught or Plow, keepeth more Draughts or Plows than one, yet he ≈øhall be Charged to find but one Cart or Wayn with Hor≈øes or Oxen; for, neither the Statute of P. and M. nor any other Statute doth Charge him to find more than one; although he that Occupies more Plow-lands than one, ≈øhall find as many Carts or Wayns with Hor≈øes as he hath Plowlands in his Occupation within your Pari≈øh.

Yet in the Kings-Bench when Hales was Chief Ju≈øtice, 2 and „Äà‚óä„Äâ P. and M. Cap. 8. the whole Court was of Opinion, That ≈øo many Draughts as any Man kept, ≈øo many he ought to ≈øend to the Highways; for ≈øo the Service they do, will an≈øwer the Damage by
them occa≈øioned to the Highways. Which Opinion ≈øeems to be very Equitable, and to ≈øquare with the Rea≈øon and Intent of the Law; and therefore if you Charge ≈øuch Per≈øons accordingly, you need not fear, (as I conceive) of the ≈øame, to be approved by the Ju≈øtices at their Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, in ca≈øe the Defaulter ≈øhall Appeal thither.
The Keeper of a Draught or Plow, you may Charge for the ≈øame, to ≈øend ≈øo many Hor≈øes with a Cart or Wayn as he u≈øually draws the ≈øame with, whether that be two, or three, or more.

Thirdly, Every Per≈øon dwelling in your Pari≈øh, 18 Eliz. Cap. 10. that Occupies a Plowland in Tillage or Pa≈øture lying in ≈øeveral Pari≈øhes, ≈øhall be Charged for all the ≈øame in your Pari≈øh where he dwells: And he or ≈øhe that dwells in another Pari≈øh, and keepeth in his or her Hands one or more Plow-lands in your Pari≈øh, ≈øhall be Charged for every of them in your Pari≈øh.

Fourthly, If any of the ≈øaid Carts and Wayns ≈øhall not be thought needful by you, to be employed upon any of the ≈øaid Six Days, then every ≈øuch Per≈øon that ≈øhould have ≈øent any ≈øuch Carriages, 2 and 3 P. and M. ≈øhould ≈øend in Lieu thereof two able Men to work for that Day.

Fifthly, Every Per≈øon and Carriage afore≈øaid, ≈øhall have and bring with them ≈øuch Shovels, and other Tools as be nece≈ø≈øary for their work, 2 and 3 P. and M. and ≈øhall do and keep their work, as you, or one of you ≈øhall appoint them Eight Hours every of the ≈øaid Six Days, unle≈øs you ≈øhall otherwi≈øe allow it.

Sixthly, In ≈øuch places where there is no u≈øe of Carts and Teams for mending the Highways, but the u≈øage is to carry Materials on Hor≈øeback, or by other kinds of Carriages; 22 Car. 2. Cap. 12. there the Inhabitants ≈øhall ≈øend ≈øuch their Hor≈øes and other Carriages in Lieu of Carts, with two able Labourers, in like manner as with Carts.

Seventhly, If any Per≈øons ≈øhall neglect to ≈øend their re≈øpective Carriages and Hor≈øes, 22 Car. 2. Cap. 12. as afore≈øaid, then the Penalty of Ten Shillings for every Days default of a Cart with two Men; and of Three Shillings for every Days default of a Man and Hor≈øe, ≈øhall be Levied in ≈øuch manner as is expre≈ø≈øed before of Day-labourers.
Al≈øo you are required to return the Defaulters within one Month after every default made, as you are before directed, to return the default of Labourers.

Eighthly and La≈øtly, If after your u≈øing all tho≈øe means herein before mentioned, the Ju≈øtices of the Peace ≈øhall be ≈øatisfied, that the Highways, Cau≈øeys, Bridges, Streets, or Pavements within your Pari≈øh, cannot be thereby ≈øufficiently repaired, then the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices, at their General Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, are to allow and order one or more A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment to be made upon the Inhabitants of your Pari≈øh, for the rai≈øing of Moneys to repair,
as need ≈øhall require, by Di≈øtre≈øs of the Goods of tho≈øe that ≈øhall refu≈øe to pay; provided that no ≈øuch A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment made in one Year, ≈øhall exceed the Rate of Six-pence in the Pound of the Yearly Value of Lands and Tenements; nor the Rate of Six-pence for Twenty Pounds in Per≈øonal E≈øtate.

Thus far I have provided to inform you of the Power, and Means, given and appointed by the Statutes for repairing the Highways; and now I ≈øhall add my own Animadver≈øion upon the manner of Charging Per≈øons to the repairing of them.

To ≈øpeak (then) plain, the way and manner of Charging Per≈øons by the Old Statutes ≈øtill in force, ≈øeems to me as unequal and oppre≈ø≈øive, as it is uncertain and ob≈øcure. And I do conceive, that to Charge all Per≈øons by an A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment only, made according to the Rate of the Poors Tax, will be more Equal, more Ea≈øie, and le≈øs Charge to the Pari≈øh, than to Charge Per≈øons by a Plow-land, and by a
Draught or Plow, and by being meer Cottagers. And this will appear evident, if all Circum≈øtances be compared and con≈øidered, of which I ≈øhall here offer only ≈øome.

Fir≈øt, By this means of Charging Per≈øons by ≈øuch an A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment, the Surveyors will be enabled to command Carriages in times needful and convenient, and with ≈øuch Carters and Labourers as will for their Hire, carry full Loads, and labour hard; whereas on the other hand, tho≈øe that are Charged to find and ≈øend in Carriages with their own Men, will Load and Draw as they plea≈øe them≈øelves for their own ea≈øe, come and go at their own time and lei≈øure, and ≈øo not perform half ≈øo much work in a Day, as the other that are Hired.

Al≈øo the Surveyors will be enabled to Hire ≈øuch Day labourers as are able, and will be Indu≈øtrious for their Hire; one of which (as I have ob≈øerved) will do more work at the Highways in one Day, than is done
by ≈øix or ≈øeven of others that come to work upon their own account as Cottagers, or that are ≈øent in by them. The≈øe are they that call them≈øelves The King's Highway-Men, when they beg of all Travellers that come near them; but they are commonly called, The King's Loyterers, who work when they li≈øt, come and go at their Plea≈øure, and ≈øpend mo≈øt of their time in ≈øtanding ≈øtill and prating, and looking after their Fellows, whom they ≈øend out from their Work, mo≈øt ≈øhamefully, to ≈øtop Pa≈ø≈øengers for a Large≈øs.

Al≈øo all Inhabitants will be A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed proportionably to what they Occupy in Lands, or Po≈ø≈øe≈øs in Goods, which is agreeable to Equity: And the Farmer or Husbandman, who doth mo≈øt hurt to the Highways, by his often Carting, for his proper Benefit, will pay the mo≈øt in the A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment, which is al≈øo rea≈øonable.

Whereas on the other hand, by the pre≈øent manner of Charging Per≈øons,
the poor Hou≈øholder or Cottager, who≈øe Family is maintained with Bread only by his daily Labour, is Charged with as much Duty to the Highways, as other Rich Inhabitants (e≈øpecially in Corporate and Market-Towns) who are worth, ≈øome of them, 500 l. 1000 l. and ≈øome, more; which is very unequal and oppre≈ø≈øive.

And although tho≈øe that keep Draughts or Carriages for Hire, and Occupy little or no Land, may, by this way of A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment, e≈øcape with paying little, and yet wear out the Highways much; that may in rea≈øon be di≈øpenced with, con≈øidering that tho≈øe Hired Carts are kept generally for the Accommodating of all the Inhabitants, as they ≈øhall have occa≈øion, paying for the u≈øe of them.

La≈øtly, By this way of Charging all Per≈øons by ≈øuch an A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment, the Surveyors may once a Year Employ poor People, and their Children, to gather tho≈øe Stones off of
Lands, that are to be gathered for repoiring the Highways, and allow them for gathering the ≈øame, after the Rate of 8 d. 10 d. or 12 d. a Cart-load, or ≈øuch a price as the Stones are truly worth to buy, when gathered; by which means the poor Labourers and their Children will be encouraged to work hard, who otherwi≈øe for want of Employment, would perhaps want Bread.

But we mu≈øt wait, and be contented with things as they are, till this Matter ≈øhall be taken into Con≈øideration by a Parliament, and altered; and in the mean time you mu≈øt Charge all Per≈øons, as the pre≈øent Laws in being have directed.
